CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure ( “ the ORG ” ) provides as follows :
“ CARDINAL . A court may quash legal incapacitation if the reasons for which it was ordered cease to exist ; the quashing may take place of the court ’s own motion .

CARDINAL . Where the mental state of an incapacitated person improves , a court may change the total incapacitation to partial ; where his or her mental state deteriorates , partial incapacitation may be changed to total . ”

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG gave judgment in case no . K CARDINAL/CARDINAL . The judgment was published and entered into force on DATE . The court decided that Article CARDINAL of the ORG was unconstitutional in so far as it deprived an incapacitated person of the right to lodge a request to have a legal incapacitation order quashed or varied . As regards the consequences of the judgment , ORG considered that the most appropriate means of enforcement would be for the legislature to introduce an amendment to LAW . In that connection it welcomed a bill under examination by ORG which included a relevant amendment . However , it emphasised that the judgments of ORG should be enforced not only by the legislature but also by the ordinary courts . In the present case that would mean changing the unconstitutional practice of courts examining cases concerning incapacitation , and allowing proceedings to be brought by individuals deprived of legal capacity . ORG stated :

“ From the date of publication of the judgment in ORG the presumption of the constitutionality of Article CARDINAL , taken together with LAW ORG , in so far as it prevented an incapacitated person from instituting proceedings to quash or vary an incapacitation order , is no longer applicable . ORG wishes to emphasise that that is so in consequence of the judgment of ORG itself , whether or not legislative changes are eventually introduced . It should therefore be considered that the finding by LAW of the unconstitutionality of limiting an incapacitated person ’s procedural rights allows the courts to interpret LAW in accordance with LAW . In the context of this judgment the opinion expressed by ORG resolution of DATE , to the effect that amelioration of the procedural position of incapacitated persons could not be achieved through interpretation of the existing regulations as that would amount to overstepping the boundaries of judicial power , is no longer applicable . Judges , when carrying out their duties , are subject not only to statute but also to the LAW , which is the highest law in GPE and may DATE and in cases of conflict with existing statutes confirmed by ORG shall – be directly applicable . ”
CARDINAL . The Law of CARDINAL DATE , which entered into force on DATE , amended the ORG . A new paragraph was added ; Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides as follows :
“ An application to have a legal incapacitation order quashed or varied may also be lodged by the incapacitated person . ”

According to the DATE LAW ( ustawa o ochronie zdrowa psychicznego ) the admission to a psychiatric hospital of a person who has a mental disorder or is mentally disabled and is unable to express his or her consent must be approved by a civil court ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) ) . A court can also decide on the admission of a person who has a mental disorder but who does not consent to treatment in the hospital . A guardian can express consent to admit an adult who is totally incapacitated , but the latter must agree too , unless he is unable to express agreement . In any event , and in particular in the event of disagreement between the patient and the guardian , the question of admission is decided or confirmed by a court ( section CARDINAL ) . Admission to the hospital is preceded by a psychiatric examination .

CARDINAL . Admission to a social care home is governed by section CARDINAL et seq . of the LAW . It provides that a person who , on account of mental disorder or mental disability , is unable to take care of himself or herself and can not be taken care of by somebody else , and does not need hospital treatment , may be placed in a social care home with his or her consent or the consent of his or her guardian . Only if the person concerned or his or her guardian does not consent to the placement must the decision be taken by a court .
